title: Unraveling in Guessing Games: An Experimental Study

findings.main_hypothesis: Distributions of choices in the first period are significantly influenced by the parameter p, suggesting players engage in a finite depth of reasoning based on p.

statistical_tests.statistical_hypothesis: Distribution of choices for p=1/2 != Distribution of choices for p=2/3
Distribution of choices for p=2/3 != Distribution of choices for p=4/3

original_data_points.description: First period mean and median choices across different parameter conditions.

p_0.5_condition.note: Corrected from paper: 3 sessions with 48 total participants (not 50)

findings.main_hypothesis: Observed choices are more concentrated in neighborhood intervals corresponding to iteration steps (50*p^n) than expected by chance.

statistical_tests.statistical_hypothesis: Concentration in neighborhood intervals (Step 1, 2) > Random chance
statistical_tests.note: Paper p. 1318: One-sided Binomial Test (not Chi-square approximation)

original_data_points.description: Concentration of choices around theoretical iteration steps.

neighborhood_definition.method: Dynamic intervals based on p and step n
neighborhood_definition.explanation: For step n, neighborhood is [50p^(n-1/4), 50p^(n+1/4)]. This is NOT a fixed ±5 interval, but depends on p and n.

p_0.5_step_1.note: Lower > Upper because p < 1, so p^(n-1/4) > p^(n+1/4)

p_0.5_neighborhoods.claim: Almost 50% concentrated in Step 1 and Step 2 neighborhoods
p_0.5_neighborhoods.note: Paper reports concentration in Step 1 and Step 2, but we test Step 0, 1, 2 for completeness

p_0.66_neighborhoods.claim: Almost 50% concentrated in Step 1 and Step 2 neighborhoods
p_0.66_neighborhoods.note: Paper reports concentration in Step 1 and Step 2, but we test Step 0, 1, 2 for completeness

p_1.33_neighborhoods.note: Data extracted from Figure 2C (Page 1317) and text descriptions (Page 1318, 1322). Round 1: Step 1-3 total ~55-60% (from Figure 2C). Rounds 2-4: percentage choosing 100 (optimal strategy).

round_1.note: ~55% of 51 ≈ 28, from Figure 2C: Step 1 (~30%) + Step 2 (~15%) + Step 3 (~10%)

round_2.note: 16% of 51 ≈ 8, from Page 1318: '100 was chosen by 16 percent in second period'

round_3.note: 59% of 51 ≈ 30, from Page 1318: '59 percent in third period'

round_4.note: 68% of 51 ≈ 35, from Page 1318: '68 percent in fourth period'

table_2_data.description: Relative frequencies (%) of choices by step classification in Periods 2-4 (Paper Table 2)

findings.main_hypothesis: In repeated rounds, choices move toward the Nash equilibrium (unraveling). For p < 1, choices decrease over time; for p > 1, choices increase over time.

statistical_tests.statistical_hypothesis: Proportion of transitions in correct direction (decrease for p<1, increase for p>1) > 0.5
statistical_tests.note: Test based on transition counts (R1->R2, R2->R3, R3->R4)

original_data_points.description: Transition counts showing directional movement over time.

p_0.5_condition.note: Sessions 1-3: 135 out of 144 transitions show decrease (below diagonal)

p_0.66_condition.note: Sessions 4-7: 163 out of 201 transitions show decrease

p_1.33_condition.note: 133 out of 153 transitions show increase (above diagonal)

p_0.5_round_4.note: More than half of observations < 1 in Round 4

findings.main_hypothesis: The rate of decrease (convergence speed) differs between p=1/2 and p=2/3 conditions, with p=1/2 converging faster.

statistical_tests.statistical_hypothesis: Median rate of decrease for p=1/2 > Median rate of decrease for p=2/3
statistical_tests.note: Test based on session-level median decrease rates (w_med)

original_data_points.description: Median rate of decrease (w_med) calculated per session from Round 1 to Round 4.

statistical_test.note: Mean rate of decrease difference was not significant, but median rate difference was significant at 5% level

findings.main_hypothesis: In Periods 2-4, players' choices relative to p × mean_{t-1} (the theoretical Step 1 target).

statistical_tests.note: Paper p. 9 Footnote 15: Weak hypothesis - choices below mean_{t-1} are significant at 1% level in all sessions and all periods

statistical_tests.statistical_hypothesis: Proportion of choices < p × mean_{t-1} in Period 4 (rejected in 6/7 sessions)
statistical_tests.reported_statistics: p < 0.01 (6 out of 7 sessions reject at 1% level)
statistical_tests.note: Paper p. 9 Footnote 15: Strong hypothesis - In Period 4, the hypothesis that choices < p × mean_{t-1} is rejected in 6 out of 7 sessions at 1% level. Periods 2-3 cannot reject this hypothesis.

original_data_points.description: Reference point test: comparing choices to p × mean_{t-1} in Periods 2-4. Session-level analysis.

weak_hypothesis.note: Significant at 1% level in all sessions and all periods

strong_hypothesis.note: Period 4: 6 out of 7 sessions reject the hypothesis that choices < p × mean_{t-1} at 1% level. Periods 2-3 cannot reject this hypothesis.

statistical_summary.note: Raw counts for individual sessions are not available in the paper. We use the reported p-values and session-level rejection counts for Pi_Human calculation.

findings.main_hypothesis: Players adjust their choices according to Learning Direction Theory: if their adjustment factor (choice/previous_mean) was above the optimal, they decrease it; if below, they increase it.

statistical_tests.statistical_hypothesis: All 7 sessions have LDT alignment rate > 50% (k=7, n=7)
statistical_tests.note: Paper p. 12: Test A - Each session is an independent observation. All 7 sessions (Sessions 1-7, p<1 only) show LDT alignment > 50%, so k=7, n=7, p0=0.5

original_data_points.description: Learning Direction Theory alignment: session-level analysis for p<1 conditions only (Sessions 1-7).

scope.note: Only p<1 conditions (Sessions 1-3 for p=1/2, Sessions 4-7 for p=2/3). p=4/3 condition is excluded.

exclusion_rule.description: Exclude transitions from participants who won in the previous round

p_0.5_condition.note: 19 winning observations excluded from 144 total transitions

p_0.66_condition.note: 23 winning observations excluded from 201 total transitions

test_a.description: Test A: Is experience irrelevant? (LDT alignment > 50% in each session)
test_a.note: All 7 sessions have LDT alignment rate > 50%, so k=7, n=7, p0=0.5

alignment_rates.note: Mean of 73% across all sessions, range 67%-78%

comparison.note: Simple 'always decrease' strategy would only achieve 58% (range 51%-69%), showing LDT is a better explanation

statistical_test.null_hypothesis: Experience is irrelevant (50% correct direction in each session)
statistical_test.result: Rejected at 1% level: k=7, n=7, p=0.0078
statistical_test.note: Paper p. 12: 'In each session, pooling the data over the three transition periods... the null hypothesis that experience is irrelevant can be rejected at the 1-percent level'

overall_original_results.description: Structured repository of numerical findings for the p-Beauty Contest experiments.

data_tables.table_name: Table 1: Means and Medians over 4 Periods
